Ayoub P good thing you don't. He falls off the bridge and into the timerift basically becoming a god. Every incarnation of him you see. From when he first returns in 8 putting siefer in his place. To the boss fights on the ffmmo's to even the spinoff games is in fact this same gilgamesh.

"Unlike other recurring characters, like¬†Cid¬†and¬†Biggs and Wedge, Gilgamesh has generally the same appearance and personality in every game he appears in. As implied in¬†Final Fantasy VIII¬†and confirmed in¬†Dissidia 012 Final Fantasy, this is because the Gilgamesh seen in the series is actually the same person, traveling between worlds via portals in the¬†Rift. When he runs across¬†Zidane,¬†Squall¬†and¬†Vaan¬†in¬†Dissidia 012 Final Fantasy, Zidane points out Gilgamesh has only two arms and thus doesn't seem familiar, alluding to Gilgamesh's appearance with four arms in¬†Final Fantasy IX."

author: Kylinu

text:
The way I've thought about it is that, I think FF XII is the best game in the Final Fantasy series, but it's not the best Final Fantasy in the series.

I expect certain kind of game every time I launch a Final Fantasy, and XII really lacked several elements that I really want in my Final Fantasy experiences. Soundtrack wasn't really as good(my little brother got excited when this song started playing during Gilgamesh fight, noting how suddenly the music got more interesting), and plot was pretty difficult to follow and not too interesting. Final battle was mostly just bothersome, and not epic at all.

XII was an awesome game, and I've been playing it through every year or so ever since it was released, and I keep finding new things on each playthrough. But it's really no Final Fantasy.

The best Final Fantasy, by the way, in my opinion is FF IX. :p
author: Joni Hanski

text:
The combat is actually much more similar to classic FF games than people realize. Every party member and every enemy has their own ATB gauge like normal.

Literally the only different thing is that you can control your character as they move. It is so similar to ff10/ff10-2's battle system it's crazy, the only difference being it's all done in an open world instead of an instanced battle, and you can control the movement.

As a huge fan of FF, I now admit I think classic turn based combat is dead. It's just too slow. It was fun while it lasted, but I think ff12 was a great evolvement of the system
author: Levianthion

text:
Sure, it's ATB at its core, but it's mostly just attempting to recreate western MMORPG battle systems using ATB. Final Fantasy series rarely just directly imitates or loans from elsewhere, usually it seems to be very creative in coming up their own ideas. As such, recreating western MMORPG battle system further strengthened the impression that it's not really a Final Fantasy game.

Final Fantasy XIII had a more Final Fantasy like extension of classic ATB system, in my opinion. I hated the game, pretty much, but that system you just could recognize as being from FF series. FF XII system you could recognize as trying to imitate FF battle systems, but it didn't really feel like the real deal.
author: Joni Hanski

text: And I mean, XII is an awesome game. I just recently spent, again, over 80 hours just exploring that world. It's a great game that was obviously made by developers that wanted to create something exceptionally good. The only thing I'm saying, the game isn't really that much a Final Fantasy.
author: Joni Hanski

text:
Personally I think XII felt just as much like a FF game as any of them, if not more so than many. X didn't feel like a FF game, aside from the combat. Neither did X-2, or XIII, again all aside from the combat. XII definitely didn't have the same feel with the music, but I think that's where that line ends.

I like FF for it's RPG elements, the story/lore, but I'd have to say the turn based ATB combat was never really my favourite part. It was slow and boring, requiring you to do no more than press "Attack" and "Cure/Potion" at low health to win, and statuses were nearly useless on anything.¬†

In XII it retains the same feel of turn based combat while being faster paced, more tactical, offering freedom of choice to use magic, statuses, different weapon types with different effects. It felt more like a FF game with it's open world, high level areas you could explore way before you should be there, super secret treasures you could find or farm, and most fun of all, hunt logs.¬†

I think most people don't like XII because it decides to change things up a little, and people don't like change. But in reality, the change was smaller than they think, not much more than adding movement to the combat. It is, IMO the best FF to date. I play it usually once a year, and each file has 100-300 hours of play time

author: Holykael1

text: Vaan and Penelo: the powerless common people, those who lose most from wars (people were complaining about Vaan and Penelo being "useless" and powerless...well duh). Basch and Ashe: the good politicians, which are usually a minority; those who take action for justice and inevitably face difficulties in the matter. Balthier and Fran: the innovators, those who choose unconventional ways to cope with their own personal difficulties and with what society cannot give them, the "deviants".
author: TheRococoVogue

text: The story is about characters facing a power much greater than they are. They face it in accordance with their own social position. I found it to be quite realistic. This story is far from forgettable if you follow it closely. It's all about political games and how they affect society and the characters themselves are a representation  of a society badly affected by politics. To go back to my first comment: it's a subtle game.
author: TheRococoVogue
